natural problem: Krista put 1 cent into her new bank on a Sunday morning.  On Monday she put 2 cents into her bank.  On Tuesday she put 4 cents into her bank, and she continued to double the amount of money she put into her bank each day for two weeks.  On what day of the week did the total amount of money in her bank first exceed $\$2$?
natural solution: The formula for a geometric series is $\frac{a-ar^n}{1-r}$. Taking $a$ to be the initial $1$-cent deposit and $n$ to be the number of days Krista had money in her bank so far, we have the inequality $$\frac{1-2^n}{1-2}\geq 200 \Rightarrow 1-2^n\leq -200 \Rightarrow 201 \leq 2^n.$$The smallest power of 2 that is greater than 201 is $2^8$.
Thus, $n=8$ and $\boxed{\text{Sunday}}$ is 7 days away from day $1$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes krista_bank :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "krista_bank 0 = 0.01"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. krista_bank (Suc n) = 2 * krista_bank n"
shows  "LEAST n. krista_bank n > 2 = 14"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Krista put 1 cent into her new bank on a Sunday morning.  On Monday she put 2 cents into her bank.  On Tuesday she put 4 cents into her bank, and she continued to double the amount of money she put into her bank each day for two weeks.  On what day of the week did the total amount of money in her bank first exceed $\$2$? The final Answer is \text{Sunday}
 ### Proof
 The formula for a geometric series is $\frac{a-ar^n}{1-r}$. Taking $a$ to be the initial $1$-cent deposit and $n$ to be the number of days Krista had money in her bank so far, we have the inequality $$\frac{1-2^n}{1-2}\geq 200 \Rightarrow 1-2^n\leq -200 \Rightarrow 201 \leq 2^n.$$The smallest power of 2 that is greater than 201 is $2^8$.
 Thus, $n=8$ and $\boxed{\text{Sunday}}$ is 7 days away from day $1$.
 *)

theorem
fixes krista_bank :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "krista_bank 0 = 0.01"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. krista_bank (Suc n) = 2 * krista_bank n"
shows  "LEAST n. krista_bank n > 2 = 14"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Krista deposited 1 cent in her bank account. Each day after that, the amount of money in her account doubles. On what day will the amount of money in her account exceed $2? The final answer is on the 14th day.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes bank :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bank 0 = 0.01"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> bank n = 2 * bank (n - 1)"
shows  "snd (SOME n. bank (fst n) > 2 \<and> n < (14, 7)) = 0"
a_1.formal solution:

 Krista put 1 cent into her new bank on a Sunday morning.  On Monday she put 2 cents into her bank.  On Tuesday she put 4 cents into her bank, and she continued to double the amount of money she put into her bank each day for two weeks.  On what day of the week did the total amount of money in her bank first exceed $\$2$? The final Answer is \text{Sunday}
 ### Proof
 The formula for a geometric series is $\frac{a-ar^n}{1-r}$. Taking $a$ to be the initial $1$-cent deposit and $n$ to be the number of days Krista had money in her bank so far, we have the inequality $$\frac{1-2^n}{1-2}\geq 200 \Rightarrow 1-2^n\leq -200 \Rightarrow 201 \leq 2^n.$$The smallest power of 2 that is greater than 201 is $2^8$.
 Thus, $n=8$ and $\boxed{\text{Sunday}}$ is 7 days away from day $1$.
 *)

theorem
fixes bank :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bank 0 = 0.01"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> bank n = 2 * bank (n - 1)"
shows  "snd (SOME n. bank (fst n) > 2 \<and> n < (14, 7)) = 0"

a_1.informal problem: You start with one cent in a bank account. Each day, the amount of money in your bank account doubles. What will be the total number of days before the amount in your bank account is more than $2? The answer is less than 14 days and 7 hours.

a_2.formal problem:
The problem described is a geometric progression. It is not straightforward to model this problem in Isabelle, since Isabelle is not well-suited for problems involving time and dates. However, the mathematical part of the problem can be modelled in Isabelle as follows:

function total :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" where
"total 0 = 0.01" |
"total n = 2 * total (n - 1)"
by pat_completeness auto
termination by (relation "Wellfounded.less_than", auto)

theorem
shows  "total 13 > 2"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Krista put 1 cent into her new bank on a Sunday morning.  On Monday she put 2 cents into her bank.  On Tuesday she put 4 cents into her bank, and she continued to double the amount of money she put into her bank each day for two weeks.  On what day of the week did the total amount of money in her bank first exceed $\$2$? The final Answer is \text{Sunday}
 ### Proof
 The formula for a geometric series is $\frac{a-ar^n}{1-r}$. Taking $a$ to be the initial $1$-cent deposit and $n$ to be the number of days Krista had money in her bank so far, we have the inequality $$\frac{1-2^n}{1-2}\geq 200 \Rightarrow 1-2^n\leq -200 \Rightarrow 201 \leq 2^n.$$The smallest power of 2 that is greater than 201 is $2^8$.
 Thus, $n=8$ and $\boxed{\text{Sunday}}$ is 7 days away from day $1$.
 *)

The problem described is a geometric progression. It is not straightforward to model this problem in Isabelle, since Isabelle is not well-suited for problems involving time and dates. However, the mathematical part of the problem can be modelled in Isabelle as follows:

function total :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" where
"total 0 = 0.01" |
"total n = 2 * total (n - 1)"
by pat_completeness auto
termination by (relation "Wellfounded.less_than", auto)

theorem
shows  "total 13 > 2"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If you start with one cent (0.01 dollars) and every day for 13 days you double the amount you had the previous day, will you have more than two dollars at the end of the 13th day?

a_3.formal problem:
fun krista_savings :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
where 
"krista_savings 0 = 1" |
"krista_savings n = 2 * krista_savings (n-1)"

theorem
shows  "(\<exists>n. krista_savings n > 200) = (\<exists>n. n = 13)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Krista put 1 cent into her new bank on a Sunday morning.  On Monday she put 2 cents into her bank.  On Tuesday she put 4 cents into her bank, and she continued to double the amount of money she put into her bank each day for two weeks.  On what day of the week did the total amount of money in her bank first exceed $\$2$? The final Answer is \text{Sunday}
 ### Proof
 The formula for a geometric series is $\frac{a-ar^n}{1-r}$. Taking $a$ to be the initial $1$-cent deposit and $n$ to be the number of days Krista had money in her bank so far, we have the inequality $$\frac{1-2^n}{1-2}\geq 200 \Rightarrow 1-2^n\leq -200 \Rightarrow 201 \leq 2^n.$$The smallest power of 2 that is greater than 201 is $2^8$.
 Thus, $n=8$ and $\boxed{\text{Sunday}}$ is 7 days away from day $1$.
 *)

fun krista_savings :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
where 
"krista_savings 0 = 1" |
"krista_savings n = 2 * krista_savings (n-1)"

theorem
shows  "(\<exists>n. krista_savings n > 200) = (\<exists>n. n = 13)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: "Krista is saving money by doubling her savings every day. On the first day, she saves $1. On which day will her savings exceed $200? The final answer is the 13th day."

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cents :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "cents 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. cents (n + 1) = 2 * cents n"
and h2 : "cents 13 > 200"
shows  "day_of_week = Sunday"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

Taking $a$ to be the initial $1$-cent deposit and $n$ to be the number of days Krista had money in her bank so far, we have the inequality $$\frac{1-2^n}{1-2}\geq 200 \Rightarrow 1-2^n\leq -200 \Rightarrow 201 \leq 2^n.$$The smallest power of 2 that is greater than 201 is $2^8$.

assumes h0 : "cents 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. cents (n + 1) = 2 * cents n"

The code appears to be a mix of unrelated statements, and the provided assumptions and conclusions do not form a coherent mathematical problem. Please provide a correct Isabelle formulation for a math problem to be translated into natural language.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and total :: int
assumes h0 : "f 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> f n = 2 * f (n-1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> total = (\<Sum>i=0..n. f i)"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 0 \<and> n < 14 \<longrightarrow> total \<le> 200"
shows  "total > 200 \<and> (\<exists>n. n = 14)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Krista put 1 cent into her new bank on a Sunday morning.  On Monday she put 2 cents into her bank.  On Tuesday she put 4 cents into her bank, and she continued to double the amount of money she put into her bank each day for two weeks.  On what day of the week did the total amount of money in her bank first exceed $\$2$? The final Answer is \text{Sunday}
 ### Proof
 The formula for a geometric series is $\frac{a-ar^n}{1-r}$. Taking $a$ to be the initial $1$-cent deposit and $n$ to be the number of days Krista had money in her bank so far, we have the inequality $$\frac{1-2^n}{1-2}\geq 200 \Rightarrow 1-2^n\leq -200 \Rightarrow 201 \leq 2^n.$$The smallest power of 2 that is greater than 201 is $2^8$.
 Thus, $n=8$ and $\boxed{\text{Sunday}}$ is 7 days away from day $1$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and total :: int
assumes h0 : "f 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> f n = 2 * f (n-1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> total = (\<Sum>i=0..n. f i)"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 0 \<and> n < 14 \<longrightarrow> total \<le> 200"
shows  "total > 200 \<and> (\<exists>n. n = 14)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Suppose a function $f(n)$ is defined recursively as follows: $f(0) = 1$ and $f(n) = 2 * f(n - 1)$ for all integers $n \geq 1$. Let $total$ be the sum of the first $n$ terms of the sequence, i.e., $total = \sum_{i=0}^{n} f(i)$. If for every non-negative integer $n$ less than 14, the sum is less than or equal to 200, find the smallest integer value of $n$ for which the sum is strictly greater than 200. The final answer is 14.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes amount_in_bank :: real
assumes h0 : "amount_in_bank = (\<Sum>k=0..13. 2 powr k) * 0.01"
shows  "amount_in_bank > 2 \<and> (\<exists>d. d = 7 \<and> d mod 7 = 0)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Krista put 1 cent into her new bank on a Sunday morning.  On Monday she put 2 cents into her bank.  On Tuesday she put 4 cents into her bank, and she continued to double the amount of money she put into her bank each day for two weeks.  On what day of the week did the total amount of money in her bank first exceed $\$2$? The final Answer is \text{Sunday}
 ### Proof
 The formula for a geometric series is $\frac{a-ar^n}{1-r}$. Taking $a$ to be the initial $1$-cent deposit and $n$ to be the number of days Krista had money in her bank so far, we have the inequality $$\frac{1-2^n}{1-2}\geq 200 \Rightarrow 1-2^n\leq -200 \Rightarrow 201 \leq 2^n.$$The smallest power of 2 that is greater than 201 is $2^8$.
 Thus, $n=8$ and $\boxed{\text{Sunday}}$ is 7 days away from day $1$.
 *)

theorem
fixes amount_in_bank :: real
assumes h0 : "amount_in_bank = (\<Sum>k=0..13. 2 powr k) * 0.01"
shows  "amount_in_bank > 2 \<and> (\<exists>d. d = 7 \<and> d mod 7 = 0)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A person deposits 1 cent, 2 cents, 4 cents, ..., up to the 13th term of a geometric sequence with a common ratio of 2, into a bank account. What is the total amount in the bank account, and is it more than 2 dollars? Additionally, is there a number divisible by 7, which is equal to 7?

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cents :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "cents 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> cents n = 2 * cents (n - 1)"
and h2 : "sum_list (map cents [0..13]) < 200"
and h3 : "sum_list (map cents [0..14]) > 200"
shows  "snd (divmod (14::nat) 7) = 0"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Krista put 1 cent into her new bank on a Sunday morning.  On Monday she put 2 cents into her bank.  On Tuesday she put 4 cents into her bank, and she continued to double the amount of money she put into her bank each day for two weeks.  On what day of the week did the total amount of money in her bank first exceed $\$2$? The final Answer is \text{Sunday}
 ### Proof
 The formula for a geometric series is $\frac{a-ar^n}{1-r}$. Taking $a$ to be the initial $1$-cent deposit and $n$ to be the number of days Krista had money in her bank so far, we have the inequality $$\frac{1-2^n}{1-2}\geq 200 \Rightarrow 1-2^n\leq -200 \Rightarrow 201 \leq 2^n.$$The smallest power of 2 that is greater than 201 is $2^8$.
 Thus, $n=8$ and $\boxed{\text{Sunday}}$ is 7 days away from day $1$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cents :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "cents 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> cents n = 2 * cents (n - 1)"
and h2 : "sum_list (map cents [0..13]) < 200"
and h3 : "sum_list (map cents [0..14]) > 200"
shows  "snd (divmod (14::nat) 7) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A sequence of amounts in cents is defined by the rule: the first term is 1 cent, and each subsequent term is twice the previous term. Find the smallest number of terms in the sequence whose sum exceeds 200 cents. The final answer is 14.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cents :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "cents 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. cents (Suc n) = 2 * cents n"
and h2 : "sum_list (map cents [0..13]) < 200"
and h3 : "sum_list (map cents [0..14]) > 200"
shows  "cents 14 > 200"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Krista put 1 cent into her new bank on a Sunday morning.  On Monday she put 2 cents into her bank.  On Tuesday she put 4 cents into her bank, and she continued to double the amount of money she put into her bank each day for two weeks.  On what day of the week did the total amount of money in her bank first exceed $\$2$? The final Answer is \text{Sunday}
 ### Proof
 The formula for a geometric series is $\frac{a-ar^n}{1-r}$. Taking $a$ to be the initial $1$-cent deposit and $n$ to be the number of days Krista had money in her bank so far, we have the inequality $$\frac{1-2^n}{1-2}\geq 200 \Rightarrow 1-2^n\leq -200 \Rightarrow 201 \leq 2^n.$$The smallest power of 2 that is greater than 201 is $2^8$.
 Thus, $n=8$ and $\boxed{\text{Sunday}}$ is 7 days away from day $1$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cents :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "cents 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. cents (Suc n) = 2 * cents n"
and h2 : "sum_list (map cents [0..13]) < 200"
and h3 : "sum_list (map cents [0..14]) > 200"
shows  "cents 14 > 200"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Suppose there is a sequence of cents where the first term is 1, and each subsequent term is twice the previous term (i.e., cents(0) = 1, cents(n + 1) = 2 * cents(n)). If the sum of the first 14 terms is less than 200 and the sum of the first 15 terms is greater than 200, show that the 15th term (cents(14)) is greater than 200.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes krista_bank :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "krista_bank 1 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> krista_bank n = 2 * krista_bank (n - 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n < 15 \<longrightarrow> (\<Sum>i=1..n. krista_bank i) < 200"
shows  "(\<Sum>i=1..15. krista_bank i) > 200 \<and> (\<Sum>i=1..14. krista_bank i) \<le> 200"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Krista put 1 cent into her new bank on a Sunday morning.  On Monday she put 2 cents into her bank.  On Tuesday she put 4 cents into her bank, and she continued to double the amount of money she put into her bank each day for two weeks.  On what day of the week did the total amount of money in her bank first exceed $\$2$? The final Answer is \text{Sunday}
 ### Proof
 The formula for a geometric series is $\frac{a-ar^n}{1-r}$. Taking $a$ to be the initial $1$-cent deposit and $n$ to be the number of days Krista had money in her bank so far, we have the inequality $$\frac{1-2^n}{1-2}\geq 200 \Rightarrow 1-2^n\leq -200 \Rightarrow 201 \leq 2^n.$$The smallest power of 2 that is greater than 201 is $2^8$.
 Thus, $n=8$ and $\boxed{\text{Sunday}}$ is 7 days away from day $1$.
 *)

theorem
fixes krista_bank :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "krista_bank 1 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> krista_bank n = 2 * krista_bank (n - 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n < 15 \<longrightarrow> (\<Sum>i=1..n. krista_bank i) < 200"
shows  "(\<Sum>i=1..15. krista_bank i) > 200 \<and> (\<Sum>i=1..14. krista_bank i) \<le> 200"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Krista is saving money in her bank account. On day 1, she saves $1. Starting from day 2, she saves twice the amount she saved the previous day. After some number of days, the total amount she has saved is at least $200. If she has not yet reached $200 by day 14, on which day does she first exceed $200 in savings? The answer is day 15.
